children.name: to work for a person, company, organization etc
work for
children.definition: to do work for a person, company, or organization:

children.name: làm việc cho ( một người, công ty , tổ chức nào đó )
examples: ▪ How long have you worked for Mr Jackson?
▪ My Dad’s been working for IBM for over twenty years.

children.name: work as something for
examples: ▪ Russell is working as a software developer for Microsoft.

children.name: be employed by/at
children.definition: be employed  to work for a company or organization, especially when you have anofficialcontractand apermanentjob:
examples: được tuyển dụng , làm việc cho ...
be employed by : được tuyển dụng bởi , làm việc cho ...
▪ She was the first woman pilot to be employed by a commercial airline.
▪ Curtis was employed by a car rental agency.

children.name: be employed at
examples: ▪ A graduate of Stanford, she is employed at Jackson, Cole, Roberts & Green, a respected law firm.

children.name: be on the payroll
children.definition: to officially work for a company or organization and to receiveregularpaymentsfor your work:
examples: là nhân công, làmcông
▪Just before the company closed in 1968, there were 300 people on the payroll.
Ngay trước khi công ty đóng cửa năng 1968, đã có khoảng 300 nhân công
be on the payroll of : làm công cho , là nhân công của
▪ Ames exposed 34 intelligence agents on the payroll of the US or its allies

children.name: be on the staff
children.definition: to be one of the people who work for a company or organization, especially when you have apermanentjobthere:

children.name: là nhân viên ( của công ty, tổ chức nào đó )
examples: ▪ Police questioned everyone on the staff at the hotel.

children.name: be on the staff of : là nhân viên của
examples: ▪ Valerie has been on the staff of the French Department at Reading University since 1992.

children.name: be with sb U
children.definition: be with somebody informalto work for a company, especially alargewell-knownone:

children.name: làm cho ( một công ty có tiếng )
examples: ▪ I believe he’s with Random House now.
▪ I used to be with the BBC, but then I got the chance of being a producer for Channel Four.

children.name: be in the pay of sb
children.definition: be in the pay ofsblàm việc cho ai( đặc biệt là bí mật )
examples: to work for someone,especially secretly

children.name: describe a job that you earn nothing form
voluntaryBritish /volunteerAmerican
children.definition: voluntaryorvolunteerworkis done by people who do it because they believe it is useful, and do not expect to be paid:

children.name: tình nguyện, tùy tâm
examples: ▪ When she retired, she did a lot of voluntary work for the Red Cross.

children.name: unpaid
children.definition: unpaidworkis work that you do but do not get paid for:
examples: ▪ Coburn works 20 to 25 unpaid hours a week for the organization.
unpaid work/service/overtime etc
công việc/ dịch vụ/ tăng ca... không lương
▪ Employees were often required to work unpaid overtime.
unpaid leave/holiday/vacation
nghỉ phép/nghỉ mát/ kỳ nghỉ không lương
▪ The company allows its employees to take unpaid leave for various reasons.

children.name: to work independently and not for sb else
self-employed
children.definition: someone who is self-employed does not have a job with one particular employer, but instead works independently and does work for many different people:
examples: làm tư, làm riêng, tự làm chủ
▪ Martin is a self-employed builder.
▪ Most fashion models are self-employed, and find work through agencies.
the self-employedpeople who are self-employed :
những người làm tư
▪ The government gives generous tax allowances to the self-employed.

self-employed/ˌself ɪmˈplɔɪd◂/ [adjective] someone who is self-employed works for a business that they own or gets paid for work by various companies or people, and is not directly employed by a single company or organization:
▪ He is a self-employed music teacher.
▪ I’ve been self-employed for over 10 years.
self-employedadjective làm tư, làm riêng; tự làm chủ
not working for an employer but finding work for yourself or having your own business
_a self-employed builder
_Do you pay less tax if you're self-employed?

children.name: have/run your own business
children.definition: to own and manage a business, especially asmallone such as a shop or restaurant:

children.name: có , vận hành công việc kinh doanh riêng
examples: ▪ She runs her own business, making and selling hand-knitted clothes.
▪ It’s always been Maria’s ambition to have her own business.
set up your own businessbegin running your own business :

children.name: thành lập kinh doanh riêng
examples: ▪ People wanting to set up their own business should take expert financial advice.

children.name: freelance
children.definition: working forseveraldifferentorganizations instead of being employed by only one - use this especially about people such as writers, designers, and photographers:
examples: làm tự do
freelance designer/journalist/photographer
▪ Jamie’s trying to earn a living as a freelance photographer.
freelance work/writing/photography etc
▪ Karen stayed at home while the children were small, and made a little money from freelance writing.
freelance[adverb]làm tự do
▪ If you work freelance from home, your hours are completely flexible.
go freelancestart working freelance after being employed by one organization : ra làm tự do
▪ I’d built up a number of contacts in the world of graphic design, so in the end I went freelance.
freelanceverb[ I ] làm nghề tự do
to work freelance
_I prefer to freelance from home rather than to work in an office.
freelanceadjective,adverb làm nghề tự do
doing particular pieces of work for different organizations, rather than working all the time for a single organization
_Most of the journalists I know are/work freelance.
_a freelance artist
freelancenoun[ C ] (alsofreelancer) người làm nghề tự do
someone who is freelance
_The firm employs several freelances.

children.name: be your own boss
children.definition: to work independently and not be employed by other people, and therefore be able to decide by yourself what you should do:

children.name: tự làm chủ, tự làm xếp cho mình
examples: ▪ I’m not good at taking orders from anybody -- I prefer being my own boss.
▪ Jim sacrificed a television career to set up in business and be his own boss.

children.name: doing sth for a job or for enjoyment
amateur
children.definition: anamateursports player, musician, actor etc does not get paid for playing, acting etc , but they do it for enjoyment:

children.name: nghiệp dư ( chơi vì yêu thích, trái với chuyên nghiệp )
examples: ▪ A group of amateur actors performed ‘Romeo and Juliet’.

children.name: for a living
children.definition: if someone does something for a living, they do it as a job in order to get money to live -use this especially about something that other people do only for fun:

children.name: để kiếm sống ( trong khi đó mọi người thường làm cho vui )
examples: She actually tastes wine for a living!
No one in the show acts or sings for a living.

children.name: professional
children.definition: alsopro  chuyên nghiệp
examples: describes someone who does a job that people usually do as a hobby
Professional basketball players can earn huge sums of money.
She's a professional dancer/photographer.
VERB + professional
turn professional(become a professional musician, player etc)
He was a keen amateur photographer for many years before he turned professional.
He's a runner who's justturnedprofessional. (= His running used to be a hobby, but now it is his job.)
professionally X[adv]
as a paid job, not as a hobby :
sing professionally
professional B2[C noun] tay nhà nghề
someone who gets paid for doing a job, sport, or activity that most people do for enjoyment :
The play is performed by 50 local actors led by four professionals.
Most athletes these days are highly-trained professionals, who spend their whole time practising or competing.
He's only been playing football as a professional for two years.

children.name: He started to sing professionally
children.definition: for money
examples: after leaving college.

children.name: amateur
children.definition: someone who does an activity or sport for enjoyment, and not as their job:
examples: dân nghiệp dư
▪ The orchestra is made up entirely of amateurs.
amateurnoun[ C ]
a person who takes part in an activity for pleasure, not as a job
_This tennis tournament is open to both amateurs and professionals.

children.name: secretary
children.definition: nounOFFICE thư ký

children.name: someone who works in an office, writing letters, making telephone calls and arranging meetings for a person or for an organization
examples: My secretary will phone you to arrange a meeting.

children.name: clerk
children.definition: noun thư ký
examples: a person who works in an office, dealing with records or performing general office duties
_afilingclerk
_a juniorofficeclerk

children.name: words for describing a job that you earn a lot from
well-paid X / highly paid
children.definition: well-paid/highly paid

children.name: lương cao
examples: ▪ There are not enough women in well-paid, responsible jobs.

children.name: pay well
children.definition: if work or a job pays well, the workers are paid a lot of money for doing it:

children.name: có lương cao
examples: ▪ Boring jobs often pay well.
▪ Modelling usually pays very well but the work is not very regular.

children.name: lucrative
children.definition: work or a particular type of business that is lucrative earns a lot of money for the people who do it:
examples: lãi nhiều , lợi nhuận cao
▪ Transferred from Barcelona to Naples, Maradona signed a highly lucrative three-year contract.
▪ An increase in consumer demand has made sports shoe retailing a lucrative business.
lucrativeadjectivecó lợi, sinh lợi
(especially of a business, job or activity) producing a lot of money
_The merger proved to be very lucrative for both companies.

children.name: administrative
children.definition: adjective hành chính
examples: relating to the arrangements and work which is needed to control the operation of a plan or organization
_administrative work
_an administrative problem
_Your responsibilities will be mainly administrative.

children.name: desk job
children.definition: nounviệc bàn giấyviệc văn phòng
examples: a job working in an office

children.name: unskilled
children.definition: adjective không cần chuyên môn
examples: unskilled workdoes not need anyparticular skills
_unskilled workers
_unskilled labour/work/jobs

children.name: piecework
children.definition: côngviệc khoán
examples: work for which the amount of pay depends on the numberof things finished rather thanthe time spent making them

children.name: showing that you have been well trained or not
professional
children.definition: adjective chuyên nghiệp ( hình thức )

children.name: approvinghaving the qualities that you connect with trained and skilled people, such aseffectiveness, skill, organization and seriousness of manner
examples: _It would look more professional if the letter was typed.
_She always looks very professional in her smart suits.
_You've done a very professional job stripping that floor!

children.name: unprofessional
children.definition: adjective không chuyên nghiệp

children.name: not showing the standard of behaviour or skills that are expected of a person in a skilled job
examples: _Doctor Rivers was charged with gross negligence, unprofessional conduct and improper use of dangerous drugs.

children.name: describe a job that you don't earn much from
low-paid
examples: Low-paid workis work that people do not get paid much money for:

children.name: low-paid job
examples: ▪ The jobs centre seems to list only low-paid temporary jobs.

children.name: not pay well
children.definition: ifworkor ajobdoes not pay well, the people who do it do not receive much money, especially considering the amount of work they have to do, the amount of knowledge they need to have etc:
examples: ▪ It used to be accepted that teaching didn’t pay very well, but things have changed a lot.

children.name: describe work that needs mental or physical effort
white-collar
children.definition: adjective  working in an office rather than in a factory, etc.; connected with work in offices:
examples: trí óc ( trái với chân tay )
a white-collar job
white-collar/ˌwaɪt ˈkɒləʳ◂ǁ-ˈkɑː-/ [adjective only before noun] white-collar worker/job/employee someone who works in an office, not a factory, mine etc:nhân viên làm việc trong văn phòng
▪ The economic recession has put many white-collar workers in danger of losing their jobs.Cuộc suy thoái kinh tế đã khiến nhiều người lao động có nguy cơ mất việc làm

children.name: blue-collar
children.definition: adjective  connected with workers who do physical work in industry
examples: blue-collar jobs/work
blue-collar/ˌbluː ˈkɒləʳ◂ǁ-ˈkɑː-/ [adjective only before noun] blue-collar worker/job/employee someone who does physical work, for example in a factory or a mine, and does not work in an office:
nhân viên văn phòng
▪ His political support comes mainly from blue-collar workers.Sự ủng hộ chính trị của ông chủ yếu là từ nhwunxg người lao động cổ áo

children.name: pink collar
children.definition: pink-collaradjective  (especially AmE) connected with jobs with low pay that are done mainly by women, for example in offices:
examples: dành cho phái nữ
pink-collaradjectivemainly US thường là do phụ nữ làm
(chẳng hạn như nghề đánh máy, trực điện thoại ...)
describes a jobthat is traditionally done by a woman
_Until recently secretarial work and nursing were very much pink-collar professions.

children.name: manual
children.definition: adjective chân tay ( khác với trí óc )
examples: involving physical work rather than mental work
_unskilled manuallabour
_750 manualworkerswill lose their jobs as a result of company cutbacks.
_Computer-controlled robots are taking over manualjobsin many industries.

children.name: to work in a types of a busines
be employed in
children.definition: : làm việc trong ...
examples: ▪ The number of people employed in the construction industry has been falling for many years.
